meanings_and_examples.definition: A wealthy or privileged person.
meanings_and_examples.example: Despite his humble beginnings, he had the means to live a life of luxury and comfort.

meanings_and_examples.definition: One who has some (contextually specified) thing.
meanings_and_examples.example: As the team captain, she had the responsibility of leading her team to victory.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To possess, own.
meanings_and_examples.example: I have a house and a car.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To hold, as something at someone's disposal.
meanings_and_examples.example: Do you have the key? (not necessarily one's own key)

meanings_and_examples.definition: Used to state the existence or presence of someone in a specified relationship with the subject.
meanings_and_examples.example: I have a really mean boss.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To partake of (a particular substance, especially food or drink, or action or activity).
meanings_and_examples.example: Can I have a look at that?

meanings_and_examples.definition: To be scheduled to attend, undertake or participate in.
meanings_and_examples.example: Fred won't be able to come to the party; he has a meeting that day.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To experience, go through, undergo.
meanings_and_examples.example: He had surgery on his hip yesterday.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To be afflicted with, suffer from.
meanings_and_examples.example: He had a cold last week.

meanings_and_examples.definition: (auxiliary verb, taking a past participle) Used in forming the perfect aspect.
meanings_and_examples.example: I had already eaten.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Used as an interrogative verb before a pronoun to form a tag question, echoing a previous use of 'have' as an auxiliary verb or, in certain cases, main verb. (For further discussion, see the appendix English tag questions.)
meanings_and_examples.example: They haven't eaten dinner yet, have they?

meanings_and_examples.definition: (auxiliary verb, taking a to-infinitive) See have to.
meanings_and_examples.example: I have to go.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To give birth to.
meanings_and_examples.example: My mother had me when she was 25.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To engage in sexual intercourse with.
meanings_and_examples.example: He's always bragging about how many women he's had.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To accept as a romantic partner.
meanings_and_examples.example: Despite my protestations of love, she would not have me.

meanings_and_examples.definition: (transitive with bare infinitive) To cause to, by a command, request or invitation.
meanings_and_examples.example: They had me feed their dog while they were out of town.

meanings_and_examples.definition: (transitive with adjective or adjective-phrase complement) To cause to be.
meanings_and_examples.example: He had him arrested for trespassing.

meanings_and_examples.definition: (transitive with bare infinitive) To be affected by an occurrence. (Used in supplying a topic that is not a verb argument.)
meanings_and_examples.example: I've had three people today tell me my hair looks nice.

meanings_and_examples.definition: (transitive with adjective or adjective-phrase complement) To depict as being.
meanings_and_examples.example: Their stories differed; he said he'd been at work when the incident occurred, but her statement had him at home that entire evening.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To defeat in a fight; take.
meanings_and_examples.example: I could have him!

meanings_and_examples.definition: (obsolete outside Ireland) To be able to speak (a language).
meanings_and_examples.example: I have no German.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To feel or be (especially painfully) aware of.
meanings_and_examples.example: Dan certainly has arms today, probably from scraping paint off four columns the day before.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To trick, to deceive.
meanings_and_examples.example: You had me alright! I never would have thought that was just a joke.

meanings_and_examples.definition: (often with present participle) To allow; to tolerate.
meanings_and_examples.example: I asked my dad if I could go to the concert this Thursday, but he wouldn't have it since it's a school night.

meanings_and_examples.definition: (often used in the negative) To believe, buy, be taken in by.
meanings_and_examples.example: I made up an excuse as to why I was out so late, but my wife wasn't having any of it.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To host someone; to take in as a guest.
meanings_and_examples.example: Thank you for having me!

meanings_and_examples.definition: To get a reading, measurement, or result from an instrument or calculation.
meanings_and_examples.example: I have two contacts on my scope.

meanings_and_examples.definition: (of a jury) To consider a court proceeding that has been completed; to begin deliberations on a case.
meanings_and_examples.example: We'll schedule closing arguments for Thursday, and the jury will have the case by that afternoon.

meanings_and_examples.definition: To make an observation of (a bird species).
meanings_and_examples.example: During our morning walk, we decided to have a closer look at the vibrant plumage and distinct call of the Northern Cardinal perched on the tree branch.
